abstract.text: The path taken by the LHC team to reach 3.6 10 ¿¿ cm ¾ s ½ instantaneous luminosity, and to deliver 5.6 fb ½ per experiment is summarized.
The main performances of the two experiments are highlighted, in particular the way they managed to cope with the already high level of "pile-up".
Selected Standard Model and top physics results are given, and the status of the limits on the Higgs boson search by each experiment is summarized.
A brief overview of the search for supersymmetry and exotic phenomena is made at the end.

body_text.text: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò
With 5.6 fb ½ of good proton-proton data delivered to AT-LAS and CMS at a centre of mass energy of 7 TeV, the performance of the LHC is considered by everyone involved as outstanding.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: The machine also delivered about 1.2 fb ½ to LHCb and 5 pb ½ to Alice, an integrated luminosity corresponding to the running conditions chosen by these experiments.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: The main parameters of the machine, at the end of the running period where the instantaneous luminosity was highest, are listed in table 1, together with the running parameters at the end of 2010, and in comparison with the nominal parameters at 14 TeV in the centre of mass [1].
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: The beam crossing angle at the collision points 1 and 5 where ATLAS (resp CMS) are installed was of 120 microradians, sufficient to limit long range beam-beam effects for a bunch spacing of 50 ns.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: The path from the 2010 parameters to those obtained at the end of this year, which represent an improvement by a factor 20, was made in successive steps: -restart of the machine with trains of bunches separated by 150 ns -beam scrubbing at injection energy and high intensity to "clean-up" the sections prone to electron-cloud effects -running with short trains of bunches separated by 50 ns e-mail: ÓÙÖÒ Ö Ð Ðº Ò¾Ô¿º Ö -intensity ramp-up with up to 1380 bunches per beam (maximum possible with 50ns spacing) -emittance reduction -¬ £ reduction from 3.5m down to 1m
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: As of early September a peak luminosity of about 3.6 10 ¿¿ at the beginning of a fill was reached, and reproduced until the end of the period (end October), allowing to record about half of the total integrated luminosity of the year during the last two months ( Fig. 1).
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: These excellent performances were obtained despite a number of effects which limited the machine availability and the actual length of most of the fills.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: Some of these effects [2] are briefly discussed below:
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: -Radiation induced failures of Electronics (SEU).
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: The cryogenics and the machine protection systems suffered from electronics failures due to radiation effects, whose rate was shown to be nearly proportional to the instantaneous luminosity.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: A number of actions were taken during the year to mitigate the incidence of such effects (relocation or shielding of critical electronics, improvement of redundancy,...).
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: -Beam dumps triggered by high losses (UFO).
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: Sudden increase of beam losses during stable conditions have been tentatively associated to "falling objects".
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: By far not all these losses trigger a beam dump.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: While during injection most UFOs happen in the vicinity of kicker magnets, losses during stable beam are more or less uniformly distributed around the machine.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: It was observed that the rate of UFOs tend to decrease during long periods of reproducible conditions.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: -Vacuum pressure increases.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: Very significant pressure increases (factors 100 or more) appeared when trains of bunches separated by 50 ns were injected in the machine.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: They were principally located around the collision points, at transition places between cold and warm sections of the machine.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: Dedicated periods at high intensity and injection energy (beam scrubbing) allowed to "clean up" the critical places, with pressure reductions of typically an order of magnitude after 15 hours.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: Wrapping simple coils around these places furthermore reduced the effect, confirming that the source was dominantly "electron-clouds".
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: -Heating of beam elements at various places (beam screen, kickers, collimators, and -recently discovered-damaged RF-fingers), associated to the electromagnetic field accompanying the bunches, was observed and forced to limit the bunch charge in several occasions.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: -RF beam loading and beam instabilities leading to emittance blow-ups were also observed at several occasions.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: As a global consequence of these various effects, the duration of beam fills was in average 6 hours, with large variations, while the optimum would have been around 12 hours.
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: Another measurement of the impact of the above limitations, is through the machine availability, which was about 50% during the "physics periods".
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: In turn about half of this time corresponded to "stable beam condition" which covered thus 23% of "physics" time (
body_text.section: ½ Ä À ÖÙÒÒ Ò Ò ¾¼½½ ½º½ Å Ò Ô Ö ÓÖÑ Ò

body_text.text: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×
Knowing the luminosity with precision is an important asset for many, if not all physics measurements.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: In 2010 the Van der Meer method was applied to measure the luminosity with an accuracy of 3.4% in ATLAS [3] and 4.0% in CMS [4].
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: In 2011 this was repeated twice.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: The method applied at the LHC goes as follows: -the machine is run with a small number of bunches -the beam current associated to each bunch is measured with a "beam current transformer" (giving n ½ and n ¾ ) -the size of the luminous region is measured by studying the counting rate as a function of beam separation, sequentially in the horizontal and vertical directions, giving È Ü and È
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: Ý .
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: This measurement is made using luminosity monitors, which are also run during high luminosity data taking.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: L is obtained as ( Ö is the rotation frequency of one bunch around the ring):
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: -integrated luminosity of long physics periods, is then obtained summing up counts from luminosity monitors, suitably corrected for various effects ( [3], [4]), and normalized to the VDM scan period.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: An example of Van der Meer scan, taken from ATLAS is shown in Fig. 3.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: The size of the luminous region is related to the counting rate R by:
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: The accuracy of the method is limited by the bunch charge measurement accuracy, and by non linearities in the luminosity monitors.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: The precision obtained for the first part of the 2011 data (until ¬ £ was lowered to 1m) is 3.7% for ATLAS and 4.5% for CMS.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: The reliability of running the machine with beams separated in one direction serves another important purpose.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: It allows to run the machine with "luminosity levelling" in LHCb, around 2 to 3 10 ¿¾ cm ¾ s ½ as requested by this experiment.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: Fig. 4 shows an example, for a given fill of how well the instantaneous luminosity is kept constant in this experiment, while it smoothly decreases in ATLAS and CMS because of proton losses and emittance increase.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: Finally the low luminosity in Alice is provided by colliding in point 2 a few dedicated bunches added to the trains.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: As a consequence of the complex bunch structure in each ring, a few "unpaired bunches" cross the nominal collision points at a time when there is no bunch coming from the other direction, thus without producing any collision.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: The data corresponding to these BCIDs (bunch crossing identifiers) are however recorded and used to evaluate the "non-collision" background, associated for the largest part to beam losses in the arcs.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: Secondaries produced when these lost protons interact in the magnet yokes, or muons from the subsequent decay of the secondaries, eventually reach the experiments and activate some low level triggers.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: Analysing these data shows [5] that, as anticipated, they mostly consist of energy deposits located in the (horizontal) machine bending plane.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: Their rate is very low, confirming the very high efficiency of the collimation process in the machine.
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: This background nevertheless needs to be rejected for some analyses looking for rare processes with rather weak signatures (jets and missing transverse momentum E Ñ ×× Ì for example).
body_text.section: ½º¾ ÄÙÑ ÒÓ× ØÝ Ñ ×ÙÖ Ñ ÒØ Ò Ù×ØÑ ÒØ×

body_text.text: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

As will be discussed in the next sections, the occurrence of several independent, inelastic, proton-proton collisions during one bunch crossing constitutes a noise, usually called pile-up noise, which degrades to some extent the performance of the reconstruction of some of the "objects" used for physics analysis.
body_text.section: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

body_text.text: It is thus important to be able to characterize the pile-up conditions on an event by event basis.
body_text.section: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

body_text.text: One essential variable in this respect is the number of primary vertices reconstructed per crossing, called N Î in the following.
body_text.section: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

body_text.text: Since the response of several detectors (in particular the calorimeters) extends over more than the time interval between two successive crossings, it is also important to have a view of the pile-up conditions in the surrounding bunches (so called "out of time" pile-up as opposed to "in-time" pile-up described by N Î ).
body_text.section: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

body_text.text: The variable used for describing the pile-up conditions overall is , the number of interactions per crossing.
body_text.section: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

body_text.text: is calculated from the suitably normalized instantaneous count of luminosity monitors (L) and the inelastic cross-section as:
body_text.section: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

body_text.text: Summing up the entries over a data taking period, one obtains the histogram of the "luminosity weighted mean number of interactions per crossing" as shown in Fig. 5 for ATLAS.
body_text.section: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

body_text.text: The dispersion reflects the variation of charges between bunches, the decrease of instantaneous luminosity during each fill, and the difference of initial conditions from fill to fill.
body_text.section: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

body_text.text: In particular the change between ¬ £ values is striking, with going from 6.3 for ¬ £ =1.5m, to 11.6 for ¬ £ =1.0m.
body_text.section: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

body_text.text: In average N Î and are roughly proportional, with N Î 0.6 , the smaller number of reconstructed vertices resulting from the limited detector acceptance, and the minimal conditions set for a valid reconstructed vertex (typically at least 3 tracks of at least 0.5 GeV/c transverse momentum).
body_text.section: ½º¿ È Ð ¹ÙÔ

body_text.text: ½º ËÔ Ð ÖÙÒ×

On top of regular "physics runs" in nominal conditions, some runs were taken in peculiar conditions to address specific questions: -Data were taken with short trains of bunches separated by 25ns in order to assess the trigger, data taking, and reconstruction performance in the future "nominal" conditions.
body_text.section: ½º ËÔ Ð ÖÙÒ×

body_text.text: -Fat bunches, of close to twice the nominal charge were also collided in order to assess the pile-up effects with reaching values of up to 40.
body_text.section: ½º ËÔ Ð ÖÙÒ×

body_text.text: -Several days in Sept 2011 were dedicated to data taking with high ¬ £ settings (90m) in view of measuring elastic scattering with dedicated forward detectors (ATLAS/ALFA and TOTEM).
body_text.section: ½º ËÔ Ð ÖÙÒ×

body_text.text: These detectors positioned at 240m on each side of the collision points 1 and 5, are located in "Roman pots" and allow to trigger and record elastically scattered protons with transverse momenta up to about 1.5 GeV/c [6].
body_text.section: ½º ËÔ Ð ÖÙÒ×

body_text.text: The beam conditions were clean enough that the detectors could be brought down to 6 from the beams for data taking.
body_text.section: ½º ËÔ Ð ÖÙÒ×

body_text.text: More than 1 million elastic events were recorded by each experiment.
body_text.section: ½º ËÔ Ð ÖÙÒ×

body_text.text: Higher ¬ £ are planned in 2012 (up to 1km) in view of reaching the Coulomb interference region.
body_text.section: ½º ËÔ Ð ÖÙÒ×

body_text.text: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×
The structure of each of the two experiments is known worldwide already.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: ATLAS [7] features an air core toroid, high granularity "accordion" lead-liquid argon electromagnetic calorimetry, complemented by Copper/liquid argon and tungsten liquid argon hadronic calorimeters in the forward direction, and iron-scintillating tiles in the central region.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: The central tracking, inside a 2T magnetic field, uses Si-pixels and Si-strips in the inner part, and straw tubes at larger radius.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: In CMS [8] the large solenoid of 4T magnetic field contains the inner detector with pixel and Si-strips, embedded in a PbWO crystal calorimeter, followed by a brassscintillating tile hadronic calorimeter.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: The forward calorimeters are recessed at 8m from the collision point and use a steel-quartz fiber (Cerenkov) sampling technique.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: Both experiments have a sophisticated 3-level trigger system, making a large use of lepton (electrons, muons, taus), high energy jet and E Ñ ×× Ì signatures.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: Up to now, the detectors have not suffered significant radiation damage.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: One observes however that the leakage current in Si-pixel sensors is increasing, in particular in CMS where, for technical reasons, the pixel detector is for the time being operated at warm temperature.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: The type inversion is expected to happen some time in 2012.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: During the past year about 4 10 ½ events were processed by the trigger system of each experiment, sollicitated at the 20 MHz bunch collision frequency.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: At the other end, about 300 events/s, in average, were written to permanent storage by each experiment.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: It is instructive to look at tables 2 and 3 which show for each experiment, at 3 10 ¿¿ peak luminosity, how the bandwidth is split between the main trigger/DAQ channels, keeping in mind that the full
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: trigger menu has about 350 lines in ATLAS, and even more in CMS.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: A good fraction of them are used to monitor the trigger itself by accepting, at each level, a prescaled fraction of the rejected events.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: Among the main signatures are the presence of one identified lepton.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: One can observe that the lepton thresholds are somewhat lower in ATLAS, thus taking in comparison a larger fraction of the bandwidth.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: Given the steep slope of the lepton (and jets) transverse momenta, it is extremely important to have sharp turn-on thresholds to reduce the rate of unwanted signals.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: As an example, Fig. 6 shows the turn-on curve for the combined muon and hadronic tau trigger, as a function of the offline tau-jet transverse momentum.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: At the storage level, the data volume is larger for AT-LAS ( 2 Mbyte/event) than for CMS ( 0.5 Mbyte/event) where zero suppression in the calorimeter is applied at the data acquisition level.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: Table 2.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: ATLAS trigger threshold and rates at the LVL1 and after final selection.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: The combined efficiency of data acquisition and data quality selection in each experiment is at a high level, allowing to find close to 90% of the delivered luminosity in the physics plots.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: The fraction of channels alive is also on a high standard, being for example 99% or more for each of the two electromagnetic calorimeters, and about 97% for each of the two pixel systems.
body_text.section: ¾ ÌÄ Ë Ò ÅË ×Ø ØÙ×

body_text.text: ¿ È Ý× × Ó Ø× Ò × Ð Ø ÓÒ Ó ËÅ Ö ×ÙÐØ×
The new feature of 2011 data was the high level of pileup, with reaching up to about 20 at the end of the period.
body_text.section: ¿ È Ý× × Ó Ø× Ò × Ð Ø ÓÒ Ó ËÅ Ö ×ÙÐØ×

body_text.text: While the pile-up "noise" is not expected to affect very high energy jets, nor lepton reconstruction, nor even b-tagging, it is on the other hand expected to affect seriously objects of large size and low/medium transverse energy, and therefore in particular:
body_text.section: ¿ È Ý× × Ó Ø× Ò × Ð Ø ÓÒ Ó ËÅ Ö ×ÙÐØ×

body_text.text: isolation of leptons and photons.
body_text.section: ¿ È Ý× × Ó Ø× Ò × Ð Ø ÓÒ Ó ËÅ Ö ×ÙÐØ×

body_text.text: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É
In the high transverse momentum (p Ì ) range, the critical quantities for jets are the energy scale and the linearity.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: In ATLAS jets are reconstructed with the anti-kT algorithm, with a size parameter R=0.6 (R=0.4 is also used for complex final states).
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: Jets are built as vectorial sums of clusters of calorimeter cells, corrected for hadronic to electromagnetic response, and dead material losses.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: In situ methods are used to check the p Ì scale up to 1 TeV or above: photon-jet balance, multi-jet balance, track-jets,.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É
¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: In 2010 the energy scale systematic uncertainty was 2.5% in a wide kinematic range.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: The large data set of 2011 may allow to improve this uncertainty.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: The ATLAS inclusive p Ì spectrum, with 1.9 fb ½ integrated luminosity, also including 2010 data on the lower p Ì part, is shown in Fig.  7.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: The data is well reproduced by a PYTHIA simulation in which the PDF are corrected for NLO effects [9].
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: Jets with p Ì up to 1.9 TeV have been observed!
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: In CMS jets are reconstructed from "Particle flow" clusters, using the anti-kT algorithm with R=0.5.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: A certain level of cluster merging ("jet grooming") is made before going to physics distributions.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: As an illustration, the invariant mass spectrum of the two jets of higher p Ì is shown in Fig. 8, compared to PYHTIA simulation (with CTEQ6L1) scaled up by a factor 1.33.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: The agreement is very good, and allows to rule out excited quarks mith masses smaller than 2.49 TeV (2.68 expected limit), Axigluons with masses lower than 2.47 TeV (2.66 expected), and W' with masses smaller than 1.51 TeV (1.40 expected).
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: ¿º¾ ÁÑÔ Ø Ó Ô Ð ¹ÙÔ ÓÒ × Ò× Ø Ú ÕÙ ÒØ Ø × -Jet energy resolution.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: The p Ì balance between photons, insensitive to pile-up given their small size, and jets allows to control the jet energy scale and resolution.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: In ATLAS it was found, in the first part of the data ( =6), that the jet energy resolution is worsened by 10% in the lowest p Ì range (30 GeV).
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: In CMS the effects of "in time pileup" and of "out of time pile-up" were separated showing that (for N Î =8) the latter contributes about 5 GeV rms to the component perpendicular to the photon direction while the former contributes about 2 times more.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: These figures correspond to the present status, without any correction to mitigate the observed worsening.
body_text.section: ¿º½ Â Ø× Ò É

body_text.text: -Lepton and photon isolation.
In order to reduce the background of fake muons coming from heavy quark decays inside jets, an isolation cut is often applied.

It consists either of a track isolation cut (sum of transverse momenta of tracks falling inside a cone of size ¡R around the muon), or a transverse energy cut (sum of all calorimeter transverse energies) or a combination of both.
Fig. 9 shows the spectrum of the calorimeter transverse energy in a cone of ¡R=0.4 around muon tracks from Z ¼ decays in ATLAS, for two pile-up conditions corresponding to N Î =4 and N Î =8.
With higher pile-up one observes a broadening of the distribution, and a shift of the mean value.
The latter can be subtracted from an estimate of the "ambient" pile-up level, but the broadening of course will stay.
The width approximately doubles when N Î goes from 1 to 12, meaning that the underlying event of Z ¼ production is more busy than for a random event.
-E Ñ ×× Ì .
Obtained as the negative vector sum of the transverse momentum of all "objects" in an event, the E Ñ ×× Ì is a priori quite sensitive to pile-up.
This dependence is limited if one retains only jets above a minimum p Ì .

As an example of performance, for a rather complex final state, Fig.  10 shows E Ñ ×× Ì in CMS (first part of 2011 data) for events with 2 leptons of opposite charge and identical flavor, in the Z ¼ mass range, plus 2 jets.
One observes that the peak of Z+ jets events remains rather narrow, and that the tail at high E Ñ ×× Ì (greater than about 70 GeV) is dominated by physical processes, essentially Ø Ø pairs.

body_text.text: Given the extreme importance of these channels, and in particular of the first three which can give rise to a narrow mass peak, a short review of the expected performance of the experiments is given below.

body_text.text: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

The huge background from jet-jet and -jet final states is mostly rejected by shower-shape cuts which take advantage of the high granularity of the "accordion" liquid argon electromagnetic calorimeter, featuring in particular three samplings in depth, and narrow strips (AE =0.008 ¢ AE =0.1) in the first sampling which provide additional rejection against jets fragmenting with a leading ¼ .
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: An additional handle is provided by calorimetric photon isolation (a typical cut is a transverse energy cut of 5 GeV in a cone of ¡R=0.4).
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: Isolation provides a way to estimate the purity of the selected sample, found to be (for m 100 GeV) 75% prompt and 25% -jets, with much smaller contributions of jet-jet and Drell-Yan • pairs.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: Thanks to the samplings in depth, electromagnetic calorimeter data alone allow to measure the polar angle of each photon, and the space angle between the two photons.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The accuracy of this measurement is illustrated by the difference in the longitudinal position of the primary vertex found by intersecting the beam line successively by each of the two photon's direction.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: This difference has an rms of 30mm, thus corresponding to a primary vertex accuracy of 15mm, well below the longitudinal spread of primary vertices (about 56 mm), and accurate enough to give a contribution to the m resolution negligible compared to the effect of the photon energies resolution.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: When one or both of the photons are converted in the inner detector volume, the coordinate of this conversion point is used, with the shower barycentre, to give an even more accurate photon direction.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The energy response of the calorimeter is calibrated using Z ¼ decays in • pairs.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: Monte-Carlo simulations are used to take into account the small differences in response between electrons, converted photons, and unconverted photons.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: With the available statistics, the calibration was made by bins of AE =0.1, without any subdivision in azimuth.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: By comparing the width of the Z ¼ line shape to Monte-Carlo simulations, this procedure also allows to estimate the "constant term" of the energy resolution, which, for the data set considered for this optimization (2010 data worth 36 pb ½ ) was 1.1 ¦0.5% in the barrel ( 1.37) and 1.8 ¦ 0.6% in the end-caps (1.52 2.37).
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The estimated average mass resolution is about 1.7 GeV for m = 130 GeV.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The spectrum obtained with 1.08 fb ½ of data is shown in fig. 20.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The 95% CL limit, normalized to the SM Higgs cross-section, times the branching ratio to the twophoton final state, is given in a small insert, showing that with this amount of data the experiment was sensitive to about 4 times the SM Higgs cross-section.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The main effort on ATLAS performances related to this channel is to improve the constant term of the energy resolution, particularly in the end-caps.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: With 100 times more data than used in the current Z ¼ lineshape optimization, it is hoped that the nominal 0.7% constant term will be reached.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The effect of higher pile-up (in particular on isolation-see section 3.2) also needs to be assessed.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The use of additional variables (transverse momentum of the system, presence of additional jets, decay angles in the system) are also being investigated.
body_text.section: º½ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

The absence of longitudinal segmentation in the PbWO4 crystal calorimeter of CMS imposes to combine the interaction vertex position with the shower positions in the calorimeter to determine the space angle between the two photons.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: The vertex is selected on the basis of the sum of the p ¾ Ì of the tracks associated to each reconstructed vertex, combined with the p Ì balance between the tracks and the two-photon system.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: For =6.5 corresponding to the analyzed data set,it was estimated by Monte-Carlo simulation that in 83% of the cases, the selected vertex is within 10mm of the true vertex, a distance small enough to give a negligible contribution to the invariant mass resolution.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: Photon identification is based on shower size and isolation.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: As opposed to ATLAS, the sum of tracks p Ì in the isolation cone (¡R=0.3) is used on its own, and combined with the transverse energy in the electromagnetic calorimeter as discriminating variable.The cut values are adjusted to give the best S/B ratio for a particular signal photon efficiency.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: In the end, the sample purity is similar to ATLAS.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: In order to eliminate crystal transparency variations as a function of the luminosity integrated in the preceding few hours/days, correction factors are determined from the crystal response to laser pulses distributed over the calorimeter during part of the cycle without collisions ("abort gap" in particular) [21].
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: The corrections range was up to about 10% for the analysed data set.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: As in ATLAS, the Z ¼ line shape is used to set the energy scale, improve the calibration, and determine the constant term.The resolution is then transported by Monte-Carlo to the two-photon final state.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: It ranges from less than 1.5 GeV for barrel-barrel events to about 3 GeV for barrel-end cap events.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: The resulting spectrum is shown in Fig. 21.

body_text.text: The 95% CL limit, normalized to the SM Higgs cross-section, times the branching ratio to the final state is given in a small insert, showing that with 1.70 fb ½ of data the experiment was sensitive to about 3 times the SM Higgs crosssection.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: In terms of detector performance, CMS is making a big effort to reach the nominal constant term which had been set to 0.5%.
body_text.section: º¾ ÌÛÓ¹Ô ÓØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÅË

body_text.text: Comparing the two experiments one can see that, combining efficiency, background rejection, accuracy in energy and angular measurements, their sensitivities are at present quite similar, as illustrated by the expected CLs limits, account taken of the relative amount of data analyzed by each experiment at the time of the Conference.

The £ 4l final state combines low background and precision mass reconstruction, the main drawback being the small branching ratio.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: Non resonant ZZ production as considered in section 2.5 is an irreducible background, while and Ø Ø are the main other backgrounds, reduced by isolation and impact parameter requirements.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The key point when addressing the low Higgs boson mass range is the reconstruction and identification efficiencies of leptons, and in particular electrons of transverse momenta down to 5 to 7 GeV.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: In an extended sample as compared to section 3.5 (up to 2.28 fb ½ ), 27 events were selected (6ee, 9e and 12 ) with one Z mass requirement (76 to 106 GeV) while 28¦4 were expected.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: One event only had a mass below 140 GeV, as shown in Fig. 22.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The main performance effort for this channel, both in ATLAS and CMS, is towards improving the efficiency of soft leptons.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: On the analysis point of view the very low mass range (below 140 GeV) may benefit from considering events where the two Z are off mass shell, an attempt already made by CMS (see talks at this Conference).
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: This decay mode is a very useful complement to in the low mass range, and a key channel for the MSSM Higgs for a large range of M and tan¬ values.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: Recently, CMS made public [22] an analysis with 1.6 fb ½ of data, using the e-, e-had and -had final states, triggered by either a lepton or a lepton plus a -jet (see section 3.3).
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The -jets are reconstructed using particle flow and identified as briefly described in 3.3.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: One of the main backgrounds is W+jets, where the W decay leptonically, and the jet is misidentified as a -jet.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: This background is rejected by cutting on the E Ñ ×× Ì projected onto the bisector of the two "visible" decay products.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The analysis is made using the invariant mass of the two visible decay products.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The sensitivity to the SM Higgs is enhanced by treating separately events with 2 additional jets in the final state, in a configuration compatible with Higgs production by Vector Boson Fusion ( ¡ 3.5 and Mjj 350 GeV).
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: No significant excess over background is seen, allowing to put a 95% CL limit at 10 times the SM Higgs cross-section for M À = 130 GeV, while the expected value ranged from around 7 at 110 GeV up to about 9 at 140 GeV.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: The sensitivity to the MSSM is enhanced by treating separately events with at least one b-tagged jet.
body_text.section: º¿ ÓÙÖ¹Ð ÔØÓÒ ¬Ò Ð ×Ø Ø Ò ÌÄ Ë

body_text.text: No excess over background is seen, allowing to rule out, at 95% CL, a large fraction of the MSSM space, as shown in Fig. 23.

body_text.text: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×
After some difficult times, the LHC has been running steadily in 2011, at 7 TeV in the centre of mass, with instantaneous luminosities reaching peak values above 3.5 10 ¿¿ cm ¾ s ½ .
body_text.section: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×

body_text.text: With such instantaneous luminosities and 50 ns bunch spacing, the average number of collisions per crossing is over 12.
body_text.section: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×

body_text.text: The ATLAS and CMS detectors have demonstrated excellent performance (including trigger and event reconstruction) in these already difficult conditions.
body_text.section: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×

body_text.text: Analyses of ElectroWeak bench mark channels show very good agreement between data and the Standard Model.
body_text.section: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×

body_text.text: With the accumulated data sets, precision physics (M ØÓÔ , M Ï ,...) can now start.
body_text.section: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×

body_text.text: No phenomenon "beyond Standard Model" has so far shown-up,but this exploration is only beginning.
body_text.section: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×

body_text.text: The hot-topic of 2011 and 2012 is the search for the SM Higgs boson.
body_text.section: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×

body_text.text: A very broad mass range has been excluded, but the best motivated low mass region (114 to 140 GeV) is still fully open.
body_text.section: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×

body_text.text: Getting the best out of present (and 2012) data, in this difficult mass range, requires pushing the precision of "objects" reconstruction, and the physics analyses, to their maximum.
body_text.section: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×

body_text.text: We look forward hearing about updates, new ideas,... during the Conference.
body_text.section: ÓÒ ÐÙ× ÓÒ×
